LouwNidaCodes66.Uni: 1A Universe, Creation; 14 Physical Events and States

AStr.Run: Use this domain for general words referring to the physical universe. Some languages may not have a single word for the universe and may have to use a phrase such as 'rain, soil, and things of the sky' or 'sky, land, and water' or a descriptive phrase such as 'everything you can see' or 'everything that exists'.
Use this domain for words related to the sky.

Use this domain for general words referring to things in the sky. Some languages may not have a single word for things in the sky, and may use a descriptive phrase or even list them, such as 'the sun, the moon, and the stars'.

Use this domain for words related to the sun. The sun does three basic things. It moves, it gives light, and it gives heat. These three actions are involved in the meanings of most of the words in this domain. Since the sun moves below the horizon, many words refer to it setting or rising. Since the sun is above the clouds, many words refer to it moving behind the clouds and the clouds blocking its light. The sun's light and heat also produce secondary effects. The sun causes plants to grow, and it causes damage to things.

Question67.AUni: (1) What words refer to the sun?
Quels sont les mots pour parler du soleil?

ExampleWords67.AUni: sun, sol, solar, daystar, our star

Question67.AUni: (2) What words refer to how the sun moves?

ExampleWords67.AUni: cross (the sky), position of the sun

Question67.AUni: (3) What words refer to the rising of the sun?
Quels sont les mots qui signifient le lever du soleil?

ExampleWords67.AUni: sunrise, sunup, dawn, daybreak, cockcrow, rise, come up

AStr.Run: We got up before
dawn
, in order to get an early start.

Question67.AUni: (4) What words refer to the setting of the sun?
Quels sont les mots qui signifient le coucher du soleil?

ExampleWords67.AUni: sunset, sundown, twilight, dusk, eventide, set, go down, sink

Question67.AUni: (5) What words describe when the sun is shining?
Quels sont les mots pour le soleil qui brille?

ExampleWords67.AUni: shine, give light, be sunny, be sunshiny, daytime, bright, come out, break through (the clouds)
Il fait du soleil, il fait jour, le jour

Question67.AUni: (6) What words describe where the sun is shining?
Quels sont les mots pour l'endroit où le soleil répand sa lumière?

ExampleWords67.AUni: sunlit, lit by the sun, shine on, be (out) in the sun, be in the sunlight, sunny (spot)

Question67.AUni: (7) What words describe when or where the sun doesn't shine?
Quels sont les mots pour l'endroit et le moment où le soleil ne brille pas?

ExampleWords67.AUni: sunless, shade, shady, shadow, eclipse of the sun, to eclipse, go in, go behind (a cloud)

Question67.AUni: (8) What words refer to the light of the sun?
Quels sont les mots pour la lumière du soleil?

ExampleWords67.AUni: light, sunlight, sunshine, ray, beam, sunbeam, radiance, glow, sparkle, glisten, glare

Question67.AUni: (9) What words describe the brightness of the sun?
Quels sont les mots qui décrivent la brillance du soleil?

ExampleWords67.AUni: bright, intense, brilliant, blinding, glaring, glistening, luminous, dim

Question67.AUni: (10) What refer to the sun heating things?
(11) What else does the sun do?
Quels sont les mots qui décrivent les effets du soleil?

ExampleWords67.AUni: makes things grow, looks down on
chauffer, sécher, répandre lumière, faire pousser les choses

Question67.AUni: (12) What words describe the damage done by sunlight?
Quels sont les mots qui décrivent les problèmes causés par le soleil?

ExampleWords67.AUni: sunburn, suntan, tan, sunstroke, heatstroke, prostration, sun damage, fading from the sun, bleached by the sun
un coup de soleil, quelque chose qui perd sa couleur dans le soleil, etc.

Question67.AUni: (13) What do people use to protect themselves from the sun?
Qu'est-ce que les gens utilisent pour se protéger contre le soleil?

ExampleWords67.AUni: sunglasses, suntan lotion, shade tree, awning, sun umbrella, parasol, sunbonnet, hat, visor
lunettes de soleil, ombre, arbre, parasol, chapeau

Question67.AUni: (14) What words are used of telling time by the sun?
Quels sont les mots qui signifient dire l'heure par le soleil?
(15) What words refer to using the power of the sun?

ExampleWords67.AUni: solar energy, solar power, solar panel

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to the moon.

Question67.AUni: (1) What words refer to the moon?
(2) What words are used for when the moon is shining?
Quels sont les mots qu'on utilise quand la lune brille?

ExampleWords67.AUni: moon is shining, moon is/comes out, by the light of the moon

Question67.AUni: (3) What words are used for where the moon is shining?
Quels sont les mots pour l'endroit où la lune brille?

ExampleWords67.AUni: moonlit, lit by the moon, shine on, be in the moonlight
clair de lune, éclairé par la lune

Question67.AUni: (4) What words are used for when or where the moon doesn't shine?
Quels sont les mots pour le moment et l'endroit où la lune ne brille pas?

une nuit sans lune, éclipse de la lune

Question67.AUni: (5) What words refer to the light of the moon?
Quels sont les mots qui correspondent à la lumière de la lune?

ExampleWords67.AUni: clair de lune, rayon de lune

Question67.AUni: (6) What words describe the effects of the moon?
Quels sont les mots qui décrivent les effets de la lune?

ExampleWords67.AUni: moon-struck, lunacy, lunatic, rising and falling of the tide
les marées hautes et basses, devenir fou à cause de la lune

Question67.AUni: (7) What words refer to the rising of the moon?
Quels sont les mots qui signifient le lever de la lune?

ExampleWords67.AUni: rising of the moon, moonrise, rise

Question67.AUni: (8) What words refer to the setting of the moon?
Quels sont les mots qui signifient le coucher de la lune?

ExampleWords67.AUni: setting of the moon, moonset, set, sink

Question67.AUni: (9) What words describe the appearance of the moon?
Quels sont les mots qui décrivent l'apparence de la lune?

ExampleWords67.AUni: man in the moon, harvest moon
(est-ce qu'on voit un animal ou une personne dans les contours de la pleine lune, par exemple?)

Question67.AUni: (10) What words refer to the phases of the moon?
Quels sont les mots qui signifient les phases de la lune?

ExampleWords67.AUni: phase, new moon, full moon, half moon, quarter moon, crescent, sliver, moon is waxing (getting bigger), moon is waning (getting smaller), wax and wane

Question67.AUni: (11) What words refer to the time it takes for the moon to go through its phases?

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to the stars and other heavenly bodies.

Question67.AUni: (1) What words are used to refer to the stars?
Quels sont les mots pour parler des étoiles?
(2) What words describe the sky when the stars are shining?
Quels sont les mots qui décrivent le ciel quand les étoiles brillent?

ExampleWords67.AUni: starlit (sky), (sky is) ablaze with stars, starry (sky), star studded (sky), stars are shining

Question67.AUni: (3) What words are used for where the stars are shining?
Quels sont les mots qui décrivent l'endroit où les étoiles brillent?

ExampleWords67.AUni: étoilé, illuminé par les étoiles, baigné par la lumière des étoiles

Question67.AUni: (4) What words are used for when or where the stars don't shine?
Quels sont les mots pour l'endroit et le moment où les étoiles ne brillent pas?

ExampleWords67.AUni: une nuit / un ciel sans étoiles

Question67.AUni: (5) What words refer to the light of the stars?
Quels sont les mots qui signifient la lumière des étoiles?
(6) What words describe the brightness of the stars?
Quels sont les mots qui décrivent la brillance des étoiles?
(7) What words describe the appearance of the stars?
Quels sont les mots qui décrivent l'apparence des étoiles?

ExampleWords67.AUni: clignoter, la forme d'une étoile, scintiller

Question67.AUni: (8) What words refer to the study of the stars?
Quels sont les mots qui correspondent aux personnes qui regardent ou qui étudient les étoiles?

ExampleWords67.AUni: astronomy, astronomer, astrology, astrologer, stargazer, magi

Question67.AUni: (9) What is a group of stars called?
Comment s'appelle un groupe d'étoiles?

AStr.Run: Use this domain for words related to planets (large objects that circle the sun, looking like bright wandering stars in the sky), comets (objects that circle the sun, looking like a star with a tail), meteors (small objects that come from space and burn up when they hit the earth's atmosphere, causing a streak of light across the sky), and asteroids (small objects that circle the sun), planetary moons (large objects that circle the planets). Some cultures do not study the stars and will have few or no words in this domain. Others cultures that study the stars will have many words.

Question67.AUni: (1) What words refer to a planet?
Quels sont les mots qu'on utilise pour une planète?

ExampleWords67.AUni: flash across the sky, blaze a trail across the sky, strike the earth, make a crater, burn up
traverser le ciel, laisser une trace, faire un cratère

Quels sont les mots qu'on utilise quand un météore frappe la terre?

AStr.Run: Unidentified Flying Object, otherwise referred to as a flying saucer

Est-ce qu'il y a un mot ou une phrase qui signifie tout ce qui vit, comprenant les plantes aussi bien que les animaux?

ExampleWords67.AUni: biology, biologist, life science, ecology, ecologist, natural history, naturalist

ExampleWords67.AUni: tissue, cell, membrane, DNA, gene, protoplasm

AStr.Run: Use this domain for general words for all plants. Use a book of pictures to identify plant names and the scientific name. Languages divide plants into various domains that are not always comparable from language to language. Critereal features may be characteristics (trees and bushes are distinguished by size and number of trunks) and use (grass and weeds are distinguished by their desirability). A common distinction is between trees and non-trees, with trees described as being big, woody, and having a life expectancy of several years, while non-trees are small, non-woody, and have a life expectancy of typically not more than one year (Heine, Bernd and Karsten Legere. 1995. Swahili plants. Rudiger Koppe Verlag: Koln.). Agricultural societies will divide plants into wild and cultivated. However most plants for which there are names have some use. Therefore it does not seem helpful to divide plant names into domains for useful and non-useful plants. Since only parts of plants are eaten, edible parts of plants are listed under the domain 'Food'. Some languages may have more domains than are used in this list, others may have fewer. The classification system used here does not agree entirely with the system used by botanists. For instance botanists do not classify all the tree species together. The palm trees belong to the class Monocotyledoneae and are classified with lilies, bananas, and orchids. Apple and cherry trees belong to the class Dicotyledoneae and are classified in the rose family along with roses and blackberries. The acacia tree also belongs to the class Dicotyledoneae and is classified in the pulse family along with lupines and beans. However most folk taxonomies bring all the trees together. The scientific classification system for plants and animals is taken from: Carruth, Gorton, ed. 1989. The Volume Library, Vols. 1 and 2. The Southwestern Company: Nashville.

Question67.AUni: (1) What words refer to all plants?
Quel mot signifie toutes les plantes, en général?
(2) What words describe types of plants?

ExampleWords67.AUni: angiosperm, annual, aquatic, biennial, bracken, brake, deciduous, creeper, flower, greens, herbaceous, hybrid, leafy, legume, luscious, parasite, perennial, plankton, pulse, sedge, succulent, tropical, vegetable, vine, weed, woody, wort

Question67.AUni: (3) What words are used to describe plants that grow wild?
Quels sont les mots qui décrivent les plantes qui ne sont pas cultivées, qui poussent naturellement dans la forêt ou la brousse?
(4) What words refer to cultivated plants?
(5) What words refer to a group of plants?

ExampleWords67.AUni: bale, bouquet, bracken, brush, bunch, canopy, clump, cluster, cover, covert, corsage, crop, culture, farrow, forest, greenery, grove, growth, hassock, haystack, herbage, jungle, kelp, nosegay, orchard, scrub, sheaf, shock, shrubbery, skein, spray, stand, sward, thicket, tuft, turf, tussock, underbrush, undergrowth, vegetation, verdure, vermin

AStr.Run: Use this domain for general words referring to mental and verbal activity. This domain is primarily for grouping many related domains. Therefore there may be no general word in a language to cover such a broad area of meaning.

Question67.AUni: (1) What general words refer to mental and verbal activity?
